thread.section_title: Commodities Market News - Yahoo!7 Australia Finance
thread.title: $A follows NZ and Canadian dollars lower
thread.title_full: $A follows NZ and Canadian dollars lower

title: $A follows NZ and Canadian dollars lower
text:
Thu, Jul 16, 2015, 5:55 PM AEST - Australia Markets closed $A follows NZ and Canadian dollars lower AAP â€“ 18 minutes ago Print 
The Australian dollar has been dragged lower by weakness in the Canadian and New Zealand dollars. 
At 1700 AEST on Thursday, the currency was trading at 73.81 US cents, down from 74.72 US cents on Wednesday. 
It dipped as low as 73.55 US cents earlier in the session, a new six year low. 
ThinkForex chief currency strategist Robert Rennie said the Aussie was taking its cues from other commodity currencies like Canada and New Zealand. 
Overnight, Canada's central bank lowered its key lending rate for the second time this year in a bid to stimulate a sluggish economy. 
"They all but confirmed a technical recession in the first half," Mr Rennie said. 
"Also last night we had a very disappointing dairy auction in New Zealand." 
The GlobalDairyTrade average winning prices sank 10.7 per cent, sending the Kiwi dollar to a fresh five-year low. 
"We (also) had a weaker than expected CPI and Westpac has changed their rate call to two per cent by the end of this year," he said. 
"We are expecting (a drop of) potentially 50 basis points as early as next week from the RBNZ." 
Mr Rennie said some traders have interpreted New Zealand's softer inflation figures as a lead indicator for Australia's own inflation data due out next week. 
At 1700 AEST, the Australian dollar was at 91.39 Japanese yen, down from Wednesday's close of 92.28 yen, and at 67.52 euro cents, down from 67.93 euro cents. 
The Australian bond market was stronger in response to the grief out of Canada and New Zealand. 
"The market is pricing in a continuation of rate cutting and Canada and New Zealand just fuel that fire, which is what's keeping our bond market supported," Nomura head of macro products Jon Linton said. 
At 1630 AEST the September 2015 10-year bond futures contract was trading at 96.985 (implying a yield of 3.015 per cent), up from 96.920 (3.080 per cent) on Wednesday. 
The September 2015 three-year bond futures contract was at 97.980 (2.020 per cent), up from 97.940 (2.060 per cent). @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook
